translated: Recorded Sayings of Chan Master Huizhao of Linji in Zhending
Compiled by the Dharma Heirs and Disciple Huiran who Resided at Sansheng
The Prefect Wang, the Attendant Censor, and the Officials invited the Master to ascend the seat. The Master entered the hall and said:
Today, I, a mountain monk, am reluctantly going along with people's feelings and ascending this seat.
If it is about proclaiming the great matter in the ancestral school, I simply cannot open my mouth, and there is no place for you to set foot.

Since the Attendant Censor is insisting today, I will not conceal the fundamental teaching. Are there any battle-hardened generals who can immediately display their battle formations and raise their flags?
Examine it in the presence of the assembly.
A monk asked:
What is the great meaning of Buddhism?
The master shouted. The monk bowed.
The master said:
This monk is indeed capable of discussion.
The monk asked the master:ğŸ”½Whose family's tune do you sing?
Whose lineage do you follow?
The master said:
At Huangbo's place, I asked three times, and was beaten three times.
The monk was about to speak, the master shouted, and then hit him, saying:
You can't drive a stake into empty space.
A lecturer asked:
Aren't the three vehicles and twelve divisions of the teachings the illumination of buddha-nature?
The master said:
The weeds have never been weeded.
The lecturer said:
How could the Buddha deceive people?
The master said:
Where is the Buddha?
The lecturer had no reply.
The master said:
In front of the prefect, you tried to deceive this old monk. Quickly leave, quickly leave, you are obstructing others' questions.
He continued:
Today's Dharma assembly is for one great matter. Are there any more who wish to ask questions?
Quickly ask your question. As soon as you open your mouth, it's already not it.
Why is it so?
Haven't you seen the Buddha say:ğŸ”½The Dharma I teach is like a raft, meant for crossing over, not for carrying.
'The Dharma is apart from words, not belonging to causes or conditions.'
Since you lack faith, I will now stop rambling, fearing it will confuse the Prefect and officials and obscure the Buddha-nature of others. It is better to just retreat.
He shouted once, saying:
Those with little faith will never have a day of completion.
I have kept you standing for a long time, take care.
The master once arrived in the capital city, and the Prefect Wang Changshi invited the master to ascend the seat.
At that time, Mazu came out and asked:
With the thousand hands and eyes of great compassion, which is the true eye?
The master said:
With the thousand hands and eyes of great compassion, which is the true eye?
Speak quickly, speak quickly!
Mazu dragged the master down from the seat. Mazu then sat down. The master came forward and said:
I do not understand.
Mazu hesitated. The master also dragged Mazu down from the seat. The master then sat down. Mazu left immediately. The master then descended from the seat.
The master said in the hall:
On this lump of red flesh, there is a genuine person without rank who always comes and goes through the faces of all of you people. Those who have not yet verified it, take a good look.
At that time, a monk came out and asked:
What is the genuine person without rank?
The master came down from the meditation seat, grabbed him, and said:
Speak! Speak!
When the monk hesitated, the master pushed him away and said:
What is this dried shit-stick of a genuine person without rank?
Then he returned to his room.
In the hall, a monk came out to pay respects. The master immediately shouted.
The monk said:
Old monk, don't stick your head out to look.
The master said:
Where do you think it falls?
The monk shouted.
Another monk asked:
What is the great meaning of Buddhism?
The master immediately shouted. The monk bowed. The master said:
Do you think that shout was good or not?
The monk said:
The grass bandit is greatly defeated.
The master said:
Where is the mistake?
The monk said:
A second offense will not be tolerated.
The master then shouted.
On this day, the two hall leaders met and simultaneously shouted.
A monk asked the master:
Are there still host and guest?
The master said:
Host and guest are clearly distinguished.
The master said:
The assembly, if you want to understand Linji's host and guest statement, ask the two hall leaders.
He then descended from the seat.
In the hall, a monk asked:
What is the great meaning of Buddhism?
The master raised his whisk. The monk shouted. The master hit him.
Again, a monk asked:
What is the great meaning of Buddhism?
The master also raised his whisk. The monk shouted. The master also shouted.
The monk hesitated. The master hit him.
The master said:
The assembly!
Those who practice the Dharma do not avoid losing their lives.
For twenty years I was with my teacher Huangbo, three times I asked about the great meaning of the Buddha Dharma, three times I was struck by him, like being brushed with mugwort branches.
Now I still want to get another beating, who can do it for me?
At that time a monk came out from the assembly and said:
I can do it.
The master picked up his staff and gave it to him. As the monk was about to receive it, the master hit him.
In the hall, a monk asked:
What is the matter on the edge of the sword?
The master said:
Disaster, disaster.
The monk hesitated, and the master hit him.
Asked:
As for the practitioner in the stone chamber who forgot to move his foot while treading the pestle, where did he go?
The master said:
Drowned in the deep spring.
The master said:
Those who come are never lacking, they all recognize where they come from.
If you come like this, it's just like losing it.
If you don't come like this, you bind yourself without ropes.
At all times, don't haphazardly make distinctions. Whether you understand or not, it's all mistaken.
Clearly speaking like this, I leave it to people of the world to criticize.
Stand for a long time, cherish respect.
He went up to the Dharma hall and said:
One person is on the peak of a solitary peak, without a way to escape;
One person is at the crossroads, also without front or back.
Which one is in front?
Which one is in the back?
Don't be VimalakÄ«rti, don't be Fu Dashi.
Cherish respect.
He went up to the Dharma hall and said:
One person discusses eons on the road without leaving home, while one person leaves home without being on the road. Which one is worthy of receiving offerings from humans and celestials?
Then he descended from the seat.
He went up to the Dharma hall. A monk asked:
What is the first phrase?
The master said:
The three essentials are revealed, the vermilion dot is on the side, before you can think, host and guest are distinguished.
Question:
What is the second phrase?
The master said:
How can wonderful understanding allow for non-attachment? How can the boat not bear the power to cut through the current?
Question:
What is the third phrase?
The master said:
Look at the puppet show on the stage, pulling and pushing all come from someone inside.
The master also said:
A single phrase must contain the three mysteries, and each mystery must contain the three essentials, with both skillful means and function.
How do you all understand this?
He then left the seat.
The master instructed the assembly during an evening session, saying:

Sometimes I take away the person but not the environment, sometimes I take away the environment but not the person, sometimes I take away both the person and the environment, and sometimes I take away neither the person nor the environment.
At that time, a monk asked:
What is it to take away the person but not the environment?
The master said:
The warm sun gives birth to brocade spread on the ground, the child's hair hanging down white like silk.
The monk said:
What is taking the situation but not taking the person?
The master said:
The king's decree has already been carried out throughout the land, the general has cut off smoke and dust beyond the borders.
The monk said:
What is taking both the situation and the person?
The master said:
The border between Bing and Fen is cut off, alone in one place.
The monk said:
What is not taking either the situation or the person?
The master said:
The king ascends the jeweled hall, the country folk sing and dance.
The master said:
Nowadays those who study the Buddha's teachings, first seek to have a true understanding.
If one attains a true understanding, then birth and death cannot taint one, and one can come and go freely. One need not seek for excellence, for excellence will come by itself.
Dao-liu!
It is just like the ancient sages of the past, all had a way to transcend the world.
As I instruct people, I just want you to not be deceived by others, to use when necessary, and not to hesitate any longer.
Why is it that students nowadays do not attain it?
The problem lies in not having self-confidence.
If you cannot be self-confident, you will be busy following all external conditions, and be turned around by myriad conditions, unable to be free.
If you can stop the mind that constantly seeks, you are no different from the buddhas and patriarchs.
Do you want to know the buddhas and patriarchs?
It is just the one listening to the Dharma in front of you.
Students do not have confidence and so seek externally.
Even if they seek and attain, they are all textual and conceptual; they will never attain the living meaning of the patriarchs.

Do not be mistaken, all Chan practitioners! If you do not encounter it now, for myriad eons and thousands of lifetimes you will revolve in the three realms, following good conditions and being reborn in the bellies of donkeys and cows.
Spiritual friends!
According to my view, it is no different from ÅšÄkyamuni.
Today, in all kinds of situations, what is lacking?
The divine light of the six destinies has never ceased for a moment. If you can see in this way, you are simply a person with nothing to do in this lifetime.
Venerable!
The three realms are unstable, like a house on fire. This is not a place for you to stay for long.
The impermanent killing ghost does not discriminate between noble and lowly, old and young, in an instant.
If you want to be no different from the buddhas and patriarchs, simply do not seek externally.
The pure light in your single thought is the dharmakÄya buddha in your house;ğŸ”½The non-discriminating light in your single thought is the sambhogakÄya buddha in your house;
The non-differentiating light in your single thought is the nirmÄá¹‡akÄya buddha in your house.
These three kinds of bodies are the person who is currently listening to the Dharma right before your eyes. It is simply because you do not seek externally that you have this function.

According to the sutras and treatises, taking the three kinds of bodies as the ultimate, according to the old monk's view, it is not so. These three kinds of bodies are names and words, and also three kinds of bases.
An ancient said:
The body is established based on meaning, the land is discussed based on substance.
The Dharma-nature body and Dharma-nature land are clearly known to be light and shadow.
Virtuous ones!
You should first recognize the one who manipulates light and shadow, which is the fundamental source of all buddhas, and the place where all those who follow the Way return.

This is not your physical body made of the four elements that can speak the Dharma or listen to the Dharma, nor is it your spleen, stomach, liver, or gallbladder that can speak the Dharma or listen to the Dharma, nor is it empty space that can speak the Dharma or listen to the Dharma. What is it that can speak the Dharma and listen to the Dharma?
It is this solitary bright form that you clearly see before your eyes. This is the one that can speak the Dharma and listen to the Dharma.
If you see it in this way, you are no different from the buddhas and patriarchs.

But at all times, do not let there be any interruption. Everything you encounter is it. It is only because of the arising of emotions that wisdom is obstructed, and because of the transformation of thoughts that the essence becomes different, that you revolve in the three realms and experience various sufferings.
If we discuss it from my perspective, there is nothing that is not extremely profound, nothing that is not liberation.
Wayfarer!

The mind-dharma has no form, and penetrates the ten directions. In the eyes it is called seeing, in the ears it is called hearing, in the nose it smells fragrances, in the mouth it speaks, in the hands it grasps, and in the feet it runs.
Originally it is one pure bright essence, divided into six sense-consciousnesses.
When the one mind is non-existent, it is liberated everywhere.
Where is the meaning of my saying this?
It is only because the wayfarer's mind cannot rest in all its pursuits, and it grasps at the idle mechanisms and realms of the ancients.

Followers of the Way, take my view: cut off the head of the Buddha of transformation and reward, the mind of the tenth stage is like a hired worker, the two kinds of wondrous awakening are a man carrying a chain, arhats and pratyekabuddhas are like filth in a latrine, bodhi and nirvana are like a stake to tether a donkey to.
Why is this so?
It's just because you followers of the Way do not understand the emptiness of three asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, and therefore have these obstructions.

If you are a true practitioner, you will never be like this. You can just follow conditions to exhaust old karma, and wear clothes as they come. If you want to walk, then walk, if you want to sit, then sit. Don't have a single thought hoping for the fruition of Buddhahood.
Why is this so?
An ancient said:
'If you want to create karma and seek Buddhahood, Buddha is a great omen of birth and death.'
Venerable Sirs!
Time is precious. You just want to go around studying Chan and the Way, recognizing names and phrases, seeking Buddha, seeking patriarchs, seeking good spiritual friends. Don't get your ideas wrong.
Dao-liu!
You only have one set of parents, what more do you seek?
You should reflect on yourself and see.
An ancient said:
Yajnadatta lost his head, seeking the mind's resting place is just being without affairs.
Virtuous one!

You should be ordinary, don't make a show of yourself. There are some bald-headed slaves who don't know good from bad, they see spirits and ghosts, point to the east and draw in the west, say it's a good sunny day and a good rain.
Such people will all have to repay their debts, one day they will swallow hot iron balls in front of Yama.
Good families' sons and daughters are possessed by this kind of wild fox demon, they then contrive strange things and are blind to the repeated births.
They will one day be asked to pay for their food.
The master addressed the assembly, saying:
Dao-liu!
You must earnestly seek the true understanding, then you can roam freely throughout the world, avoiding being confused and deluded by these kinds of demons.
Doing nothing is being a noble person. Just don't create, just be ordinary.
If you want to go outside and seek faults and find support elsewhere, you're mistaken.
If you just want to seek Buddha, Buddha is a name and phrase.
Do you recognize the one who is seeking?
The Buddhas and Ancestors of the three times and ten directions have come forth just to seek the Dharma. Now the practitioners who study the Way are just seeking the Dharma.
Only after attaining the Dharma will it be done. If not attained, one will continue to transmigrate through the five paths.
What is the Dharma?
The Dharma is the Dharma of the mind. The Dharma of the mind is formless, penetrating the ten directions. It is presently used in the eyes.
If people cannot believe it, they will recognize names and phrases, and seek understanding in written words. The Dharma of the Buddhas and Patriarchs is far from that.
Dao-liu!
When I, Shan-seng, speak the Dharma, what Dharma do I speak?
I speak the Dharma of the mind-ground, which can enter the sages, enter the ordinary, enter the pure, enter the defiled, enter the true, and enter the mundane.
It's not that you, ordinary or holy, can give names to all ordinary or holy, true or mundane. Ordinary or holy, true or mundane, cannot give this person a name.
Dao-liu!
Grasp it and use it, don't give it a name, call it the profound purport.

This mountain monk's teaching is different from that of others. If Manjushri and Samantabhadra were to appear, manifesting themselves in the present moment, as soon as they said, We ask the teacher, I would have already discerned them.
This old monk sits at ease. When other Dao-liu come to see me, I discern them all.
Why is this so?
It's because my perspective is different. Externally, I do not accept ordinary or holy; internally, I do not dwell in the fundamental. Seeing through, I no longer doubt or err.
The master addressed the assembly, saying:
Dao-liu!
In the Buddha Dharma, there is no need for effort. It is just ordinary, nothing special - defecating, urinating, putting on clothes, eating, and when tired, lying down...
Fools laugh at me, but the wise understand.
An ancient said:
Making effort externally is all foolish and stubborn.

You should be the master everywhere, and wherever you stand is true. When conditions come, they cannot change you. Even if you have habitual tendencies and the five heinous crimes from the past, they will naturally become the great ocean of liberation.

Nowadays practitioners do not recognize the Dharma at all. They are like a nose-touching sheep that encounters an object and puts it in its mouth. They cannot distinguish master from slave, host from guest. Such people enter the path with a deviant mind and cannot enter noisy places. They are called true renunciant monks, but they are actually true lay householders.

Those who leave the household must discern the ordinary, true, and correct understanding - discerning Buddhas, discerning demons, discerning the true, discerning the false, discerning the ordinary, discerning the sagely...
If you can discern in this way, it is called true leaving the household.

If you cannot discern demons and Buddhas, you are simply leaving one household to enter another household, and are called a sentient being who creates karma, not yet worthy of being called a true renunciant.
Now there is one who treats Buddhas and demons as having the same essence and not distinguishing them, like water and milk mixed together, with the king of geese eating the milk.
If you are a clear-eyed practitioner, you beat both demons and Buddhas.
If you love the sagely and hate the ordinary, you will float and sink in the ocean of birth and death.
A question was asked:
What is a Buddha?
What is a demon?
The master said:
The place where your mind has a thought of doubt is a demon;
If you can penetrate the non-arising of myriad dharmas and understand that the mind is like an illusion, without a single dust or dharma, everywhere pure, that is a Buddha.

However, the Buddha and Mara are two tainted and pure realms. From my perspective, there is no Buddha, no sentient beings, no past, no present. If one attains it, it is attained immediately, not through time. There is no cultivation, no realization, no gain, no loss, and no other Dharma at any time.
If there is a Dharma that surpasses this, I say it is like a dream, like an illusion.
What I say is all true.
Dao-liu!

The solitary and bright one who listens right now, this person is unhindered everywhere, penetrating the ten directions, freely in the three realms, and cannot be changed by entering all realms and distinctions. In an instant, he penetrates the Dharma realm, encountering the Buddha to speak of the Buddha, encountering the patriarchs to speak of the patriarchs, encountering arhats to speak of arhats, encountering hungry ghosts to speak of hungry ghosts. He travels to all lands to teach and transform sentient beings, never leaving a single thought. In every place, he is pure, his light penetrating the ten directions, and the myriad dharmas are one suchness.
Dao-liu!

Great and courageous ones, only now do you realize that originally there is nothing to do. It is just that you cannot believe it, and moment to moment you run after it, abandoning your head to search for your head, unable to rest on your own.

Like the perfect and sudden bodhisattvas who enter the Dharma realm and manifest their bodies in the Pure Lands, they are weary of the ordinary and delight in the sacred. Those in such a state have not forgotten about accepting and rejecting, and still have a mind attached to purity.
But the understanding of the Chan school is not like this. It is precisely the present moment, without any time.
What I, the mountain monk, say are all temporary remedies for illnesses, and there is no real Dharma at all.
If you see it like this, then you are truly leaving the household life, and you will consume ten thousand ounces of gold every day.
Dao-liu!
Do not be casually certified by the teachers of various places, saying that you understand Chan, understand the Way, and are eloquent like a waterfall, as all of this is creating the karma for hell.
If you are a true practitioner of the Way, you do not seek to surpass the world, but urgently seek the true understanding.
If one penetrates the true and correct view, understanding is perfect and clear, and only then is it completely understood.
A question was asked:
What is the true and correct view?
The master said:

You just enter the ordinary and the sacred, enter the defiled and the pure, enter the buddha-lands, enter Maitreya's tower, and enter Vairocana's Dharma realm. Everywhere, lands are seen forming, abiding, decaying, and becoming empty. Buddhas appear in the world and turn the great wheel of the Dharma, and then enter nirvana. No coming or going is seen. Seeking birth and death, it cannot be found. One then enters the Dharma realm of non-arising and travels to various lands. Entering the Flower Treasury world,

one sees all phenomena as empty, all without true reality. Only those who listen to the Dharma and have no attachment are the mothers of the buddhas. Therefore, the buddhas are born from no attachment.
If one realizes no attachment, the buddhas are also unobtainable.
If one sees in this way, this is the true and correct view.
Students do not understand and cling to names and phrases, being obstructed by the names and labels of ordinary beings and sages, thus obscuring their Dharma eye and preventing it from being clear.

The twelve divisions of the Buddhist canon are all teachings that reveal and illustrate, but students do not understand and give rise to understanding based on the names and phrases that reveal and illustrate, all of which rely on and fall into causes and effects, not avoiding the birth and death of the three realms.
If you want to be free from the bondage of coming and going in birth and death, then right now recognize the one who listens to the Dharma:
It has no form, no characteristics, no roots, no basis, and no dwelling place.

It is lively and active, responding to myriad arrangements, and in its use there is nowhere it is not. Therefore, the more you seek it, the farther it moves away, and the more you pursue it, the more it goes against you. It is called the secret.
Dao-liu!
Do not cling to this dream-like illusory companion, for sooner or later it will return to impermanence.
What are you looking for in this world that you seek liberation? Look for a meal to eat and pass the time mending your robe. You should seek out teachers and not waste time pursuing pleasure.

Time is precious, every moment is impermanent. Grossly, you are bound by earth, water, fire, and wind. Subtly, you are oppressed by the four characteristics of arising, abiding, changing, and ceasing.
Dao-liu!
Now you should recognize the four kinds of formless realms to avoid being tossed about by external conditions.
A monk asked, What are the four kinds of formless realms?
The master said, When a thought of doubt arises in your mind, you are obstructed by earth.
When a thought of love arises in your mind, you are drowned by water.
When a thought of anger arises in your mind, you are burned by fire.
When a thought of joy arises in your mind, you are blown by wind.

If you can discern in this way and not be turned by objects, you can use objects everywhere - rising in the east and sinking in the west, rising in the south and sinking in the north, rising in the center and sinking in the periphery, rising in the periphery and sinking in the center, walking on water as if on land, and walking on land as if on water.
Why is it so?
It is because you have realized the four elements are like a dream and an illusion.
Followers of the Way!
The one who is listening to the Dharma right now is not your four elements that can be used.
If your four elements could see in this way, then you would be free to come and go.
According to my view, do not dislike the Dharma.

If you love the sages, the sages are just names. There are some practitioners who seek MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« in the Wutai Mountains, but they are already mistaken, for there is no MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« in the Wutai Mountains.
If you want to know MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«,
it is just in your present functioning, always the same, everywhere without doubt - this is the living MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«.
In a single thought-moment, the mind is without distinctions, and everywhere is truly Samantabhadra.
In a single thought-moment, the mind itself can untie bonds and be liberated everywhere, this is AvalokitÃªÅ›vara.

The dharmas of samÄdhi mutually serve as primary and secondary, and when they emerge, they emerge simultaneously. One is three, and three is one. If you understand in this way, then you can begin to read the teachings.
The master addressed the assembly, saying:
Now, those who study the Way should first of all have self-confidence and not seek externally. They are all entangled in external dust and phenomena, and do not distinguish right from wrong.
There are ancestral teachers and buddhas, all of whom are matters within the traces of the teachings.

There are people who pick up a single phrase of speech, either hidden or manifest, and immediately give rise to doubt, illuminating heaven and earth, seeking answers from others. They are very confused.
Great men should not just discuss the host and the thief, right and wrong, form and wealth, and pass the days talking idly.

In this mountain monk's place, I do not distinguish between monks and laypeople. As long as they come, I recognize them all. No matter where they come from, as long as there are sounds, names, phrases, and sentences, they are all dream-like illusions.

I see that the person who rides the circumstances is the profound purport of the buddhas. The buddha circumstances cannot call themselves buddha circumstances. It is still this person without reliance who rides the circumstances and comes out.
If someone comes out and asks me about seeking buddhahood, I will respond by coming out in the pure circumstances.
If someone asks me about bodhisattvas, I will respond by coming out in the circumstances of compassion.
If someone asks me about bodhi, I will respond by coming out in the circumstances of purity and wonder.
If someone asks me about nirvana, I will respond by coming out in the circumstances of tranquility.
Circumstances are of myriad distinctions, but the person is not different. Therefore, responding to things and manifesting forms is like the moon in water.
Wayfarers!
If you want to attain according to the Dharma, you must be a true great being.
If it is a place of withering and following, then it is not allowed.
A vessel that is cracked and hoarse cannot contain ghee.
As for a great vessel, it simply means not being deceived by others, acting as the master in any situation, and wherever it is placed, it is true. But those who come cannot receive it.
If you have a single thought of doubt, then demons will enter your mind. When bodhisattvas have doubts, the demon of birth and death finds an opportunity.
You can only put an end to thoughts and not seek externally. When objects come, then illuminate them.
You simply believe in what is being used right now. There is not a single thing.
A single thought in your mind gives rise to the three realms. Following conditions and being divided by objects, it is divided into the six sense objects.
What is lacking in your current application?
In a single instant, you enter the pure, you enter the defiled, you enter Maitreya's tower, you enter the land of the three eyes. Traveling everywhere, you only see empty names.
A question:
What is the land of the three eyes?
The master said:
I enter the pure and wondrous realm with you, wear pure and clean clothes, and expound the Dharma-body Buddha;
Again, I enter the realm of no distinctions, wear clothes of no distinctions, and expound the reward-body Buddha;
Again, I enter the realm of liberation, wear clothes of radiance, and expound the transformation-body Buddha.

These three realms of eyes are all based on transformation. According to the sutras and treatises, they take the Dharma-body as the fundamental, and the two bodies of reward and transformation as the function.
As for my understanding, the Dharma-body does not understand how to expound the Dharma.
Therefore, the ancients said:
'The body is established based on meaning, and the realm is discussed based on substance.'

The Dharma-nature body and Dharma-nature realm are clearly established dharmas based on the realm of emptiness. Using an empty fist and yellow leaves to deceive children, looking for juice on the thorns and bones of tribulus terrestris, what is it?
Outside the mind there are no dharmas, and internally they cannot be obtained either. What are you looking for?
You all speak in various ways:
'The Way can be cultivated and realized.'
Don't be mistaken, if there is cultivation and attainment, they are all the karma of birth and death.
You say to cultivate the six pÄramitÄs and myriad practices equally, I see them all as creating karma.
Seeking Buddha and seeking the Dharma is creating the karma of hell;
Seeking bodhisattvas is also creating karma;
Reading sÅ«tras and teachings is also creating karma.
Buddhas and patriarchs are people with nothing to do, therefore, with outflows and conditioned, without outflows and unconditioned, is pure karma.

There are some blind monks who, after eating their fill, sit in meditation, observing and controlling thoughts to prevent them from arising, weary of noise and seeking stillness, which is the Dharma of non-Buddhists.
The patriarchs say:
'If you dwell on the mind, observe stillness, raise the mind to look externally, gather the mind internally, or congeal the mind in samÄdhi, all such states are creations.
How do you now listen to the Dharma? How do you intend to cultivate it, realize it, or adorn it?
It is not something that can be cultivated, nor is it something that can be adorned.
If you want to adorn it, then all things can be adorned. Don't be mistaken.
Daoist!
You take the words in the mouths of these kinds of teachers to be the true Way, and that the good and wise advisors are inconceivable.
'I am an ordinary person, and dare not measure the elders.'
Blind!
You have spent your whole life only having this kind of understanding, betraying this pair of eyes, cold and numb like a frozen donkey on a frozen river.
'I dare not slander the good and wise advisors, afraid of creating verbal karma.'
Daoist!

A great good and wise advisor dares to slander the Buddha, slander the patriarchs, judge the world, reject the teachings of the Tripiá¹­aka, scold the young, and seek people in the midst of going against and following. Therefore, for twelve years I sought a single karmic nature, even as small as a mustard seed, and could not find it.
If it were like the Chan master Xin Fuzi, he would be afraid and chased out of the monastery, not given food to eat, not comfortable or happy.
From ancient times, the seniors were not believed wherever they went, and only after being expelled did they become known as valuable.
If everyone everywhere were to agree with them, what would be the use?
Therefore, when the lion roars, the jackals' brains split.
Daoist!
The various directions say there is a path to cultivate and a Dharma to realize.
What Dharma do you say is realized?
What path do you say is cultivated?
Right now, what thing is lacking in your use?
What place needs to be repaired?

Later, a young monk who did not understand, immediately believed this kind of wild fox spirit, allowed him to speak things that bind people, saying that the principle and practice must correspond, and that protecting the three karmas will lead to becoming a buddha. Such talk is like a fine spring rain.
An ancient said:
If you meet a person of the Way on the road, do not tell them.
Therefore it is said:

If a person cultivates the Way but it does not progress, myriad kinds of deviant states compete to arise. When the sword of wisdom appears, there is no single thing. The bright side has not yet manifested, but the dark side is clear.
Therefore, an ancient said:
Ordinary mind is the Way.
Virtuous ones!
What are you seeking?
The Dharma-free person who is currently listening to the Dharma is vividly clear, never lacking.
If you want to be no different from the buddhas and patriarchs, just see in this way, do not doubt or err.
Your mind not being different from moment to moment is called the living patriarch.
If the mind is different, then nature and characteristics are separate;
Since the mind is not different, then nature and characteristics are not separate.
He asked:
What is the place where the mind and mind are not different?
The master said:
When you intend to ask, it is already different. Nature and characteristics are each divided. Way-seeking people, do not be mistaken.
All phenomena in the world and beyond the world have no self-nature and also no arising nature. There are only empty names, and even the names are empty.
You just take those idle names as real, greatly mistaken.
If there are, they are all dependent on changing realms.

There is a dependence on enlightenment, a dependence on nirvana, a dependence on liberation, a dependence on the three bodies, a dependence on the realm and wisdom, a dependence on bodhisattvas, a dependence on buddhas.
In the lands that depend on change, what are you seeking?
Up to the three vehicles and the twelve divisions of the canon, they are all rags for wiping dirt.
The Buddha is an illusory body, the patriarchs are old monks. Have you been born by your mother yet?
If you seek the Buddha, you will be captured by the demon of the Buddha;
If you seek the patriarchs, you will be bound by the demon of the patriarchs;
If you have any seeking, it is all suffering. It is not as good as having no affairs.
There are some bald monks who tell students:
'The Buddha is the ultimate. After cultivating for three incalculably long eons, he finally attained enlightenment.'
Wayfarers!
If you say the Buddha is the ultimate, why did he lie down between the twin trees in the city of KuÅ›inagara eighty years later and die?
Where is the Buddha now?
It is clear that he is no different from our birth and death.
You say the thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks are the Buddha. Then a wheel-turning sage king should be the TathÄgata. It is clear that this is an illusion.
An ancient said:
'The TathÄgata's entire physical form is in accordance with worldly sentiments. Fearing people would give rise to the view of annihilation, he provisionally established a false name.
The thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks are just empty sounds. The body is not the essence of enlightenment, only the formless is the true form.
You say the Buddha has the six supernormal powers, which is inconceivable.
All the gods, immortals, asuras, and powerful ghosts also have spiritual powers, should they be Buddhas?
Daoist, don't be mistaken. For example, when the asuras fought with Indra, they were defeated and led their 84,000 retinue into the hole of a lotus root to hide.
Are they sages?
What I have mentioned are all karmic powers and dependent powers.

As for the Buddha's six spiritual powers, it is not so. Entering the realm of form is not deluded by form, entering the realm of sound is not deluded by sound, entering the realm of smell is not deluded by smell, entering the realm of taste is not deluded by taste, entering the realm of touch is not deluded by touch, entering the realm of dharmas is not deluded by dharmas. Therefore, one penetrates the six kinds of form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas, all of which are empty characteristics, unable to bind.
This person of no reliance, although possessing the five aggregates and outflows, is a deity with spiritual powers on the ground.
Followers of the Way!

The true Buddha has no form, the true Dharma has no characteristics. You merely create illusory transformations on the basis of this, and if you seek to attain them, they are all wild fox spirits, not the true Buddha. This is the understanding of non-Buddhists.

As for a true practitioner of the Way, they do not take up Buddha, do not take up bodhisattvas or arhats, do not take up the extraordinary of the three realms, are completely independent and not bound by things, have no further doubts even if heaven and earth are turned upside down, and do not have a single thought of joy even if all the buddhas of the ten directions appear before them, and do not have a single thought of fear even if the three evil destinies and hells suddenly appear.
Why is this so?

I see the empty nature of all phenomena, which exist when transformed and do not exist when not transformed. The three realms are only mind, and the myriad dharmas are only consciousness. Therefore, dreams, illusions, and empty flowers are not worth grasping.

Only the person who is currently listening to the Dharma before the Way-farer's eyes, when entering fire is not burned, when entering water does not drown, when entering the hells of the three evil destinies it is like strolling in a garden, and when entering hungry ghosts and animals does not receive retribution.
Why is this so?
It is because there is no fault in the Dharma.
If you love the sages and detest ordinary people, you will sink and float in the ocean of birth and death.
Afflictions arise from the mind, without mind, what can afflictions constrain?
Without bothering to discriminate and grasp at characteristics, you will naturally attain the Way in an instant.

If you intend to study by going to various places, even after three asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas you will still return to birth and death. It is not as good as having nothing to do and sitting with crossed legs at the foot of a bed in a monastery.
Dao-liu!
When students from various places come, the host and guest meet, and then there is a sentence of speech.
They discern the previous good teachers who were brought out by the students, and the students throw a phrase of skillful means at the good teachers' mouths to see if they recognize it or not.
If they recognize it as a state, they grab it and throw it into a pit.
The students then act as usual, and then they demand the good teachers' words, which are taken back as before.
The students say:
This is a great good teacher with the highest wisdom!
They then say:
You are very ignorant of what is good and what is not.
It is like a good teacher holding up a piece of the objective realm in front of a student, and the student, discerning it, acts as the host and is not deluded by the objective realm.
The good teacher then reveals half of himself, and the student shouts.
The good teacher then enters into all the paths of differentiated speech and rolls around, and the student says:
An old bald-headed slave who doesn't know good from bad.
The good teacher praises him, saying:
A true spiritual heir.

If the good teachers of various places do not discern right from wrong, when a student comes and asks about bodhi, nirvana, the three bodies, objective realms, and wisdom, the blind old teachers will explain it for them. If they are scolded by the students, they will grab their staffs and hit them, saying:
Lacking propriety.
It is because the good teachers themselves lack eyes that they cannot be angry with others.

There are some bald-headed slaves who don't know good from bad, who point to the east and draw lines in the west - good weather, good rain, good lanterns, good pillars - they look at your eyebrows and see how many hairs there are. This kind of student with conditions and circumstances does not understand, and then their mind goes crazy.
Such people are all wild fox spirits, demons, and monsters. They are laughed at by good students, who say, The blind old bald-headed slave confuses people all over the world.
Dao-liu!
Monks should study the Way. As for me, I once focused on the Vinaya, and I also searched through the sutras and treatises.
Later I realized they were medicines for saving the world and teachings for revealing the truth. So I threw them all away at once and visited teachers to study Chan.
Later I met a great virtuous teacher and only then did my Way-eye become clear. I finally recognized the world.
The old monk knows their right and wrong. It's not that they understand upon birth, but rather that they investigate and refine until they suddenly realize on their own.
Dao-liu!

If you want to attain the correct understanding, just don't be deceived by others. Encountering things inside and outside, kill them all - kill the Buddha when encountering the Buddha, kill the patriarchs when encountering the patriarchs, kill the arhats when encountering arhats, kill your parents when encountering your parents, kill your relatives when encountering your relatives - only then will you attain liberation.
Not bound by things, you will be liberated and free. But those who study the Way in various places have not come out without relying on things.

Here I strike them from head to toe - if they come out with their hands, I strike their hands; if they come out with their mouths, I strike their mouths; if they come out with their eyes, I strike their eyes. Not a single one has come out on their own. They all rely on the old masters' idle states of mind and realms.
I have not a single Dharma to give to people. I only treat illnesses and untie bonds.
Then, you practitioners from all directions, try to come out without relying on things, and I will discuss with you.

For ten years and five years, there was not a single person, all of them were spirits of grass, leaves, bamboo and wood, wild fox demons, who randomly bit at all the lumps of excrement, blind fools, vainly consuming the offerings of the faithful from the ten directions, saying they are renunciant sons, having such views, I tell you:
'There is no Buddha, no Dharma, no cultivation, no realization, just like this, by the side of the house, what other thing are you seeking?'
Blind fools, adding a head on top of your head, what are you lacking?
Practitioners!
What you use right now is no different from the buddhas and patriarchs, yet you just don't believe it and go seeking outside.
Don't be mistaken, there is no Dharma outside, and it cannot be obtained within either.
You take the words from my mouth, it's better to just rest and do nothing.
If you have already given rise to [afflictions], do not continue them; if you have not yet given rise to them, do not let them arise. This is better than ten years of wandering.
According to my view, there are not so many kinds of things. I just wear clothes, eat meals, and spend time as usual.
You who come from various places all have the intention to seek Buddha, seek the Dharma, seek liberation, and seek to leave the three realms.
Fools!
Where do you want to go to leave the three realms?
Buddhas and patriarchs are names and phrases for those who are bound by rewards.
Do you want to know the three realms?
They are not apart from the mind-ground of you who are now listening to the Dharma.
Your one thought of greed is the desire realm, your one thought of anger is the form realm, and your one thought of delusion is the formless realm. These are the furniture in your house.
The three realms do not say:
I am the three realms.
Still, Wayfarer!
The person who is vividly present before you, illuminating and discerning myriad things, and measuring the world, is given the name of the three realms.
Great virtuous one!

The four great elements and the physical body are impermanent, up to the spleen, stomach, liver, gallbladder, hair, fur, nails, and teeth, only seeing the characteristics of the emptiness of all phenomena.
The place where your mind rests for a moment is called the Bodhi tree;
The place where your mind cannot rest for a moment is called the tree of ignorance.

Ignorance has no dwelling place, ignorance has no beginning or end. If your mind cannot rest moment by moment, you ascend the tree of ignorance and enter the six realms, four forms of birth, covered in fur, or with horns;
If you can rest, it is the pure body realm.

If there is not a single thought, then you are on the bodhi tree. The spiritual transformations of the three realms, the mind-born transformation body, the joy of the Dharma, the bliss of meditation, the light of the body illuminating by itself, thinking of clothes, brocade and gauze in a thousand layers, thinking of food, a hundred flavors complete, no more illness.
Bodhi has no place to abide, therefore there is no one who attains it.
Dao-liu!
What more do you doubt, great man?
In the present usage, who else is it? Grasp it and use it, do not attach names, it is called the profound purport. Seeing it like this, there is no dharma to dislike.
An ancient said:
The mind follows myriad phenomena, turning, the turning place is truly profound. Following the flow, recognizing the nature, no joy, no sorrow.
Dao-liu!

In the Chan school, the understanding of life and death is clear. Those who study and practice must be very careful. When host and guest meet, there is conversation back and forth. Sometimes they manifest form in response to things, sometimes they use the whole body, sometimes they display joy and anger, sometimes they appear half-bodied, sometimes they ride a lion, sometimes they ride an elephant king.
If there is a true student, they will shout and first pick up a lacquer basin.
The good teacher of the Way does not discern that it is a situation, and immediately acts on top of it.
The student then shouts, and the teacher in front does not agree to let go.
This is an incurable illness, called the guest looking at the host.
Or, the good teacher of the Way does not pick up anything, but seizes wherever the student asks.
The student, having been seized, holds on to death and does not let go. This is the host looking at the guest.
Or, there may be a student who responds with a pure situation in front of the good teacher of the Way. The good teacher of the Way discerns that it is a situation and grabs it to throw it into a pit.
The student said:
Great good teacher!
He immediately said:
Tsk tsk, not knowing good from bad.
The student then bowed, this is called the host looking at the host.
There are students who come out in front of the good teacher with shackles and chains, and the good teacher adds another layer of shackles and chains, and the student is delighted.
Not distinguishing between the two, it is called the guest looking at the guest.
Venerable!
The examples I have given are all for distinguishing demons and distinguishing differences, knowing their evil and right.
Daoist!
It is truly difficult, the Buddha Dharma is profound, understanding is acceptable.

This mountain monk has been talking about it all day, but the students don't care at all. They step over it a thousand times and ten thousand times, it's pitch black, not a single form, yet it is solitary and bright.

If students do not have faith, they will give rise to understanding based on names and phrases. Even when they reach fifty years old, they will just follow others, carrying a dead body, carrying a burden, running all over the world, looking for money for straw sandals. One day they will find it.
Venerable!
I say there is no Dharma outside.

Students do not understand, so they immediately give rise to understanding within, sit leaning against a wall, with the tongue touching the palate, still and unmoving, taking this to be the Buddha Dharma of the Ancestral Gate.
This is a great mistake. If you take the still and pure realm to be it, you are recognizing ignorance as your master.
The ancients said:
The deep pit of dark stillness is truly terrifying.
This is it.
If you recognize movement as it, since all grasses and trees can move, they should be the Way.
Therefore, movement is the wind element, stillness is the earth element, movement and stillness are both without self-nature.
If you grasp him where he moves, he stands where he does not move;
if you grasp him where he does not move, he stands where he moves.
It is like a fish hiding in the deep water, stirring up waves and leaping by itself.
Great Virtuous One!
Moving and not moving are two kinds of objects, but they are still without reliance. The person of the Way uses movement and stillness.

As for students coming from all directions, in this place of mine I make a threefold distinction of spiritual capacity:ğŸ”½If those of middling and lower spiritual capacity come, I immediately deprive them of their objects while not eliminating their principles;
If those of middling and superior spiritual capacity come, I immediately deprive them of both objects and principles;
If those of superior and superior spiritual capacity come, I immediately neither deprive them of objects, principles, nor people;
If there are people with extraordinary understanding who come, in this place of mine I immediately employ the entire essence without regard to spiritual capacity.
Great Virtuous One!
At this point, where students exert themselves, there is no wind passing through. Even lightning and sparks have already passed by.
If a student's eyes move, there is no connection. If you form thoughts, you are mistaken. If you have moving thoughts, you go against it.
If someone understands, it is not apart from the present moment.
Great virtuous one!
You carry your alms bowl and run around seeking Buddha and Dharma elsewhere. Do you recognize the one who is running around seeking like this right now?

It is lively and active, just without roots and branches, not gathering when pressed together, not scattering when pushed apart. If you seek it, it moves further away. If you don't seek, it is right in front of you.
The spiritual sound belongs to the ears. If a person does not believe, it is in vain for a hundred years.
Dao-liu!

In an instant, they enter the Flower Treasury world, enter the land of Vairocana, enter the land of liberation, enter the land of spiritual powers, enter the pure land, enter the Dharma realm, enter the defiled and the pure, enter the ordinary and the holy, enter the hungry ghosts and animals, searching everywhere, but in the end they do not see any birth or death, only empty names.
Illusory transformations and empty flowers are not worth grasping; gain and loss, right and wrong, are all put aside at once.
Followers of the Way!

This monk's direct transmission of the Buddha Dharma comes from Chan Master Magu, Chan Master Danxia, Chan Master Daoyi, and Chan Master Lu Shan who pulled stones. Traveling all over the world, no one believes it and all slander it.
As for Chan Master Daoyi's use, it is pure and without mix-ups. Three to five hundred students all fail to see his meaning.
It's like how the Venerable of Mount Lu was truly autonomous, using in accordance with circumstances, whether favorable or adverse. Students could not fathom his limits and were all bewildered.
It's like how the Venerable of Danxia played with the pearl, concealing and revealing. Those students who came were all scolded.
It's like how the usage of Magu was as bitter as that of Huangbo, and few could approach him.
It's like how the usage of Shigong was to seek people on the tip of his arrow. Those who came were all afraid.
It's like how my usage today is truly creating and destroying, playing with spiritual transformations, entering all realms, and being at ease everywhere, with realms unable to change me.

But if there are those who come seeking, I will then appear to see them. If they do not recognize me, I will put on a few kinds of robes. Students give rise to understanding and enter my words and phrases one-sidedly:
'Alas, the blind bald man without eyes! The people take the robes I wear and identify them as blue, yellow, red, and white. I take them off and enter the realm of purity.
Students, upon seeing it, immediately give rise to delight.
I then took off the robe, and the student lost his mind, panicked, and ran around, saying:
I have no clothes!
I then said to him:
Do you recognize the person wearing the robe?
Suddenly he turned his head and recognized me.
Venerable Sir!

Do not recognize the robe. The robe cannot move. The person can wear the robe. There is the pure robe, the robe of non-arising, the robe of bodhi, the robe of nirvana, the robe of the ancestors, the robe of the Buddha.
Venerable Sir!

All sounds, names, and phrases are all transformations of the robe, arising from the churning of the qi sea at the navel and the knocking of teeth, forming their meaning. Clearly, they are illusory transformations.
Venerable Sir!
External sounds and speech are the karmic activity of speech, while internal mental states are expressed through thoughts. All of these are robes.
You just take what you've grasped as the real understanding, and even if you pass through countless eons, it's only the clothes of the three realms, cycling through birth and death.
It's not as good as having nothing to do, meeting without recognizing each other, speaking together without knowing each other's names.

Nowadays students don't get it, because they take names and words as understanding. They copy the words of dead old men on large boards, wrap them in three or five layers of cloth, and don't let people see them, saying they are the profound purport and take them as precious.
Big mistake, blind to the extreme!
What juice are you looking for in a dried-up skeleton?

There are some who don't know good from bad, who take the meaning in the teachings and discuss it, forming into phrases and meanings, like taking a lump of shit and putting it in their mouths, then spitting it out and giving it to others.
It's like laypeople passing on oral instructions, wasting their whole lives.

When he was asked about the Buddha Dharma, he immediately became speechless, his eyes like a lacquer doll's, his mouth like a hanging beam. Such a person, even if Maitreya appears in the world, will be banished to another world and suffer in hell.
Great Virtuous One!
Where are you going to seek what?
Your feet are wide, there is no Buddha to seek, no Way to accomplish, no Dharma to attain.
Seeking an embodied Buddha outside, it is not similar to you. If you want to know your original mind, it is neither in union nor separation.
Wayfarer!

The true Buddha has no form, the true Way has no substance, the true Dharma has no characteristics. The three dharmas are mixed and fused together in one place. Since discrimination cannot reach it, it is called the busy karmic consciousness of sentient beings.
Asked:
What is the true Buddha?
The true Dharma?
The true Way?
Please bestow an explanation.
The master said:
The Buddha is the purity of the mind;
The Dharma is the radiance of the mind;
The Way is the unobstructed pure light everywhere.
The three are one, all empty names, without true existence. A true practitioner of the Way, moment by moment, the mind is uninterrupted.
Since the Great Master Bodhidharma came from the West, he was just looking for someone who is not deceived by others.
Later, he met the Second Patriarch, and upon a single word, it was resolved. Only then did he know that all his previous efforts were in vain.
My understanding today is no different from the Buddhas and Patriarchs. If one attains in the first phrase, one becomes a teacher of the Buddhas and Patriarchs;
If one attains in the second phrase, one becomes a teacher of humans and gods;
If one attains in the third phrase, one cannot save oneself.
A monk asked:
What is the meaning of the coming from the West?
The master said:
If there is a meaning, one cannot save oneself.
The monk said:
Since there is no meaning, how did the Second Patriarch attain the Dharma?
The master said:
Those who attain are not attaining.
He said:
If it is not attaining, why is it the meaning of not attaining?
The master said:
It is because you seek everywhere, and your mind cannot rest.
Therefore, the patriarchs said:
'Alas, a man!
Carrying his head to seek his head.'
If you turn the light and reflect back right under your words, and no longer seek elsewhere,
knowing that your body and mind are no different from the buddhas and patriarchs, then you are called one who has attained the Dharma.
Virtuous ones!
I, a mountain monk, now have no choice but to speak out these many faults.
You should not be mistaken. According to my view, there are truly not so many kinds of principles. If you want to use them, use them; if you don't want to use them, just stop.

As for the various places speaking of the six pÄramitÄs and myriad practices as the Buddha Dharma, I say they are the gate of adornment and the gate of Buddha's affairs, not the Buddha Dharma. Even upholding precepts and observing the precepts, carrying oil without spilling, and not having the eye of the Way, all must repay debts, and there will be a day to collect the alms money.
Why is this so?
If one enters the Way but does not understand the principle, one will return to the body and repay the offerings of faith.

The elder is eighty-one, but the tree does not grow ears. Even living alone on a solitary peak, eating only one meal at dawn, sitting for a long time without lying down, practicing the six periods of worship, all are people who create karma. Even giving away one's head, eyes, marrow, brain, country, city, wife, children, elephants, horses, and the seven treasures, such views all cause suffering to the body and mind, and thus attract suffering as a result. It is not as good as having nothing to do, pure and unadulterated.

Even the bodhisattvas at the stage of the tenth ground who have fulfilled their minds all seek this path, but its traces are utterly unobtainable. Therefore, the celestial beings rejoice, the earth spirits support his feet, and the buddhas of the ten directions all praise him.
Why is this so?
It is because the present Dharma listeners have no traces of their activities.
Asked:
The Buddha MahÄbhijÃ±ÄjÃ±ÄnÄbhibuddhah sat at the site of enlightenment for ten eons, but the Buddha Dharma did not manifest before him, and he did not attain Buddhahood.
I do not know what this means.
Please instruct me, Master.
The master said:
The great penetrating one is oneself, penetrating everywhere the myriad dharmas have no nature and no characteristics, called the great penetrating one.
The superior wisdom is not doubting or obtaining a single dharma anywhere, called superior wisdom.
The Buddha is the mind being pure, the light penetrating the Dharma realm, and attaining the name of Buddha.
Sitting at the site of enlightenment for ten eons is the ten perfections.
As for the Buddha Dharma not being manifest, the Buddha originally does not arise and the Dharma originally does not perish, so how could there be anything more manifest?
As for not being able to attain Buddhahood, the Buddha should not become a Buddha again.
An ancient person said:
The Buddha always abides in the world, yet is not tainted by worldly dharmas.
Dao-liu!
If you wish to become a Buddha, do not follow myriad things.
When the mind arises, various dharmas arise; when the mind ceases, various dharmas cease. If the one mind does not arise, myriad dharmas are faultless.
In the world and beyond the world, there is no Buddha, no Dharma, and also nothing manifest, nor ever lost.
If there are any, they are all names, phrases, and sentences, used to guide the ignorant and prescribe medicine according to the illness, to illustrate and reveal names and phrases.

Moreover, names and phrases do not name themselves. It is still the clear and bright, spiritual and aware, perceptive and knowing, illuminating and radiant essence before one's eyes that establishes all names and phrases.
Virtuous One!
One who commits the five heinous crimes will attain liberation.
He asked:
What are the five heinous crimes?
The master said:
Killing one's father, harming one's mother, drawing blood from a Buddha, breaking up the harmonious Sangha, burning scriptures and images, these are the five heinous crimes.
He said:
What is the father?
The master said:

Ignorance is the father. When you seek the arising and ceasing of a single thought, you cannot find it. Like an echo responding to emptiness, following circumstances without any affairs, this is called killing the father.
He said:
What is the mother?
The master said:

Craving and love are the mother. When you enter the desire realm with a single thought and seek its craving and love, you only see the empty characteristics of all dharmas, and are unattached everywhere, this is called harming the mother.
He said:
What is drawing blood from a Buddha?
The master said:
When you do not give rise to a single thought of understanding in the pure dharma realm, and everywhere is dark, this is drawing blood from a Buddha.
He said:
What is breaking the harmony of the Saá¹ƒgha?
The master said:
Your one thought mind directly penetrates afflictions and fetters, like space with nothing to rely on, this is breaking the harmony of the Saá¹ƒgha.
He said:
What is burning the scriptures and images?
The master said:

Seeing the emptiness of causes and conditions, the emptiness of mind, and the emptiness of dharmas, with a single thought of determination and severing, completely free from affairs, is burning the scriptures and images.
Great virtuous one!
If you understand in this way, you will avoid being obstructed by the names of ordinary and holy beings.

Your one thought mind only gives rise to real understanding on top of empty fists and pointing, and falsely grasps weirdness within the faculties, objects, and dharmas, belittling yourself and retreating, saying:ğŸ”½'I am an ordinary person, he is a holy person.'
Bald one!
What is the hurry?
Wearing the skin of a lion, yet howling like a fox.

Great men should not act with the breath of a man. They do not believe in the things in their own homes, and just go outside to seek after the idle names and phrases of the ancients. They rely on the yin and yang, unable to be unique and straightforward. They encounter circumstances and give rise to conditions, encountering dust and grasping, touching everywhere and giving rise to delusion. They are not self-consistent.
Dao-liu!
Do not take what I say as the truth.
Why is it so?
Because what is said has no basis.
It is like painting in empty space, like painting a picture.
Dao-liu!
Do not take the Buddha as the ultimate, as the view of self is like a latrine hole.
Bodhisattvas and arhats are all fetters and chains that bind people.
Therefore, Manjushri wielded a sword to kill Gautama, and Angulimala held a knife to harm Shakyamuni.
Dao-liu!
There is no Buddha to be attained, and even the three vehicles, five natures, and perfect and sudden teachings are all temporary remedies for illnesses, and none are real dharmas.
If there are, they are all similar, expressed in words, arranged in texts, and explained like this.
Dao-liu!
There are some bald-headed monks who make effort right there, intending to seek the Dharma of leaving the world, they are mistaken.
If a person seeks the Buddha, this person loses the Buddha;
if a person seeks the Way, this person loses the Way;
if a person seeks the Patriarchs, this person loses the Patriarchs.

Great Virtuous Ones, do not be mistaken. I do not accept your understanding of the scriptures and treatises; I also do not accept your kings and ministers; I also do not accept your eloquence like a cascading waterfall; I also do not accept your intelligence and wisdom. I only want your true and correct understanding.
Dao-liu!
Even if you understand a hundred scriptures and treatises, it is not as good as one who has nothing to do.

If you understand this, you immediately despise others, compete with asuras, give rise to the ignorance of self-view, and create the karma for a long time in hell, like the bhiká¹£u Sunaká¹£atra who understood the twelve divisions of the scriptures, and was reborn in hell in his current body, with the earth unable to contain him.
It is better to just let it be, to rest, to eat when hungry, and to sleep when tired. Fools may laugh at me, but the wise will understand.
Wayfarers!

The master's name was Yixuan, and he was from Nanhua in Caozhou. His secular surname was Xing. From a young age, he was extraordinary. As an adult, he was known for his filial piety.
After being tonsured and receiving full ordination, he stayed in a lecture hall, diligently studying the Vinaya, and extensively studying the scriptures and treatises. Suddenly, he sighed and said:
This is the medical prescription for saving the world, not the purport of the special transmission outside the teachings.
He then changed his robes and traveled to various places. He first visited Huangbo, and next went to Dayu. The stories and dialogues are recorded in his biography.

After receiving Huangbo's seal of approval, he then went to a small temple on the southeast corner of the city wall in Hebei, beside the Huosha River, where he stayed. Linji got its name from this place.
At that time, Puhua was already there, pretending to be crazy and mingling with the crowd, his holiness and ordinariness unfathomable.
When the master arrived, he assisted him.
When the master was in full swing of teaching, Puhua completely let go of his body, thus fulfilling the prediction of Xiaoshizi of Mount Nanyue.

At that time, there was a military conflict, so the master left immediately. The Minister of State Affairs, Mo Junhe, donated his house in the city to build a temple, also named Linji, and invited the master to reside there.
Later, he shook his sleeves and went south to the capital of Henan. The prefect Wang Changshi extended to him the courtesy of a teacher.
After staying there for a while, he went to the Xinghua Temple in the capital of the Great Name Prefecture and resided in the east hall.

The master, without illness, suddenly one day arranged his robe, sat upright, finished asking and answering with the Three Sages, and peacefully passed away, on the tenth day of the first month in the eighth year of the Tang Xianchun era, the dinghai year.

The disciples built a stupa for the master's whole body in the northwest corner of the Great Name Prefecture, and the posthumous title of Chan Master Huizhao was bestowed, with the stupa named Chengleng.
